stem: The nurse is reviewing the electronic health record of a client with acute kidney injury (AKI). Which of the following findings should the nurse immediately report to the provider?

rationale.correct: A potassium level of 6.2 mEq/L is critically elevated and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and death. This requires immediate intervention to prevent life-threatening complications. Hyperkalemia affects the resting membrane potential of cardiac cells, making them more excitable and prone to arrhythmias.

mnemonic.hyperkalemiaSigns: MURDER (Muscle weakness, Urine (oliguria/anuria), Respiratory distress, Decreased cardiac contractility, ECG changes, Reflexes (hyperreflexia, or areflexia (flaccid))

rationale.incorrect: Elevated BUN and creatinine levels are expected findings in AKI due to the kidneys' reduced ability to filter waste products, but do not require the same level of immediate intervention as hyperkalemia. While these values indicate impaired kidney function, they do not pose the same immediate threat to life.

questionTrap.trap1: Students may focus on the elevated BUN and creatinine as the primary problem in AKI, overlooking the immediate danger of hyperkalemia. This is because BUN and creatinine are commonly associated with kidney dysfunction, but hyperkalemia presents a more acute and life-threatening risk.
questionTrap.trap2: Students may not recognize the normal range for potassium and therefore not recognize the severity of the hyperkalemia. A normal potassium range is typically 3.5-5.0 mEq/L, so 6.2 mEq/L is significantly elevated.

clinicalPearls: Hyperkalemia is a life-threatening electrolyte imbalance that is common in patients with AKI.
ECG changes associated with hyperkalemia include peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, and widened QRS complex.

Treatment for hyperkalemia may include calcium gluconate, insulin and glucose, sodium bicarbonate, and/or dialysis. Calcium gluconate stabilizes the cardiac membrane, while insulin and glucose shift potassium into cells.

itemContext.sbar:
14:00, SBAR for Mr. Johnson:
Situation: Mr. Johnson, 68-year-old male, admitted 2 days ago with acute kidney injury (AKI), likely secondary to dehydration.
Background: History of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and insulin glargine.
Assessment: Patient is currently on IV fluids and strict I&O monitoring. Urine output has been decreasing over the last 12 hours. Patient reports increasing fatigue and muscle weakness.
Recommendation: Please evaluate the patient for possible hyperkalemia and consider adjusting his medications and IV fluid regimen. Stat labs were drawn.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
14:00, SBAR for Mr. Johnson:
Situation: Mr. Johnson, 68-year-old male, admitted 2 days ago with acute kidney injury (AKI), likely secondary to dehydration.
Background: History of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and insulin glargine.
Assessment: Patient is currently on IV fluids and strict I&O monitoring. Urine output has been decreasing over the last 12 hours. Patient reports increasing fatigue and muscle weakness.
Recommendation: Please evaluate the patient for possible hyperkalemia and consider adjusting his medications and IV fluid regimen. Stat labs were drawn.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
BP: 160/90 mmHg
HR: 98 bpm
RR: 22 breaths/min
Temp: 37.2°C (99.0°F)
O2 Sat: 96% on room air

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content:
Na: 140 mEq/L
K: 6.2 mEq/L
Cl: 100 mEq/L
BUN: 60 mg/dL
Creatinine: 3.5 mg/dL
Hgb: 11.5 g/dL
Hct: 34.5%

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Lisinopril 20mg daily
Metformin 1000mg twice daily
Insulin glargine 20 units daily
IV fluids: 0.9% Normal Saline at 75 mL/hr
